Posts.Title: Cutting Tamoxifen Dose? shelly56 shelly56

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2011 04:24AM - edited Nov 28, 2011 04:25AM by christina1961 Absolutely.  I was diagnosed 2/5/11 and Jan 2010 I had gone to my GP - I never went to the doctor; worked a zillion hours a week, worked through the flu, etc - but I was so tired that I went to get bloodwork to see if anything was wrong.  Nothing unusual in my bloodwork.  During a brief period between my first chemo (6 rounds of TAC) and surgery, I was walking 3-4 times a week and actually seemed to have more energy than pre diagnosis.  Now that I've had almost a year of treatment, I stay tired (but I'm on chemo again). I am looking FORWARD to being done with all this in February and hopefully will start regaining some stamina.
Posts.Title: Anyone have problems with fatigue prior to diagnosis? cfdr dlj140

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2012 07:11AM - edited Jan 19, 2012 07:12AM by christina1961 I am currently on Halaven on a clinical trial. They give me Aloxi for nausea and decadron. I had them reduce the decadron by half after the first infusion. I have had at least six infusions at the reduced dose without any problem. I will try to remember to ask tomorrow exactly how many milligrams I am getting because I wouldn't want to report the wrong amount. Even at half amount, it gives me energy that last two days then I crash.
Posts.Title: Halaven or Decadron? sincitydealer sincitydealer

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2012 08:53AM christina1961 wrote: Peggy, I asked yesterday what I was getting - 4 mg decadron with the halaven and aloxi for nausea.  I get 1 mg of ativan with my infusion, too- I don't take it any other time but when I get infused.  I believe they may have had me at 12 mg at first, but I know it was at least at 8.  Also, I've had 9 infusions so far and have held onto my head hair but eyebrows have fled the coop. Opposite of what happened with TAC. One reason I reduced the decadron was the horrible crash I had.  I hope that is what is going on with your mom - if she was that energized from the decadron then she probably is just crashing and should be better soon. I'm sorry she is going through all this.  The fatigue I get with this chemo is much less than TAC but it seems to last longer.  The trial nurse told us yesterday that they are hearing really good things about this chemo.
Posts.Title: Halaven or Decadron? sincitydealer sincitydealer

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2012 12:25AM christina1961 wrote: I have a uniMX with no reconstruction for now and I also have upper back kyphosis. I got a hard foam roll on amazon.com - it is 3 feet long and about 6-8 inches wide. It is flat on one side. I put it on the floor, put a pillow under my head and lay with the curved part of the roll parallel with my spine every night for about 15 minutes. It helps "undo" some of the shoulders curving in that I get working on a keyboard for hours and hours a day. It also helps stretch my scar (my MX was in July.)
Posts.Title: Concerning Posture and Sleeping crystalphm topless

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 09:30AM christina1961 wrote: I don't have enough to do a TRAM flap but the local PS said he can do a lat flap.  I know one of his patients who had lat flap on both sides and she looks great!  Having said that, I am nervous about losing my lat muscle as I have some existing back issues so i am also exploring other options.  I am also going to ask him if he would try implant reconstruction and go really small.  I had augmentation prior to BC so if the implant was removed from my "good" side then I would only have to match an A cup.That would be ok with me at this point - I just want to be able to wear my clothes and someday a bathing suit.
Posts.Title: Seemingly impossible decision CindyT littletower

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 10:15AM christina1961 wrote: I finished radiation in October following a unilateral MX.  I have some shooting pains in the breast area and under my arm (had 16 nodes removed) when I carry heavy things.  When I touch the breast area, it is certainly sensitive and the ribs are still sensitive.  For a few days I took lots of ibuprofen and the pain minimized quite a bit - in my case I think it is the cartilage and serratous muscles treated in the radiation field causing most of my pain. I go to physical therapy and have exercises to help keep the scar tissue from modeling into a configuration that could limit my shoulder mobility.
Posts.Title: pain 5 months after radiation cherb Mimikub56

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2011 01:53PM christina1961 wrote: Wow, Special K - that is horrible!  I took it luckily without incident when I had a fever during TAC chemo.  I had kind of a dull headache but no other problems.  I was scared of it, too - but scared not to take it - like so much of this treatment as I know you all understand. I also had a slight staph infection following surgery and had to take Sulfa - I had thought I was allergic to it because it made me throw up as a child.  My surgeon said that was not a true allergic reaction and he wanted me to try it because it was very effective against staph.  I did - and amazing, had absolutely no problems with it after years of telling everyone I was allergic to it. It cleared up the infection quickly.
Posts.Title: Levaquin (levofloxacin) TAPPY TAPPY

Posts.Title: PET Results CoolBreeze ruthbru

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2011 12:50AM christina1961 wrote: I hope it is ok to respond as I am not Stage 4 but I am on Halaven in a clinical trial because I have a high risk for recurrence.  I have now had 3 cycles (six doses) at I believe 1.4 mg per infusion.  I get two infusions every three weeks (one week off.)  I feel like I have the flu - bone and muscle aches - but very little nausea. I have also had fatigue, but get my infusion on Fridays and usually am back to work by Tuesday.  I've heard that it has helped many, and I'm sure you will get more replies shortly.  Oh - in the clinical trial, I am not allowed to have any Neulasta or Neupogen shots and so far my GR has gotten to .7 for about a week each three week cycle. I have also stayed slightly anemic, although a couple of the weekly readings showed me in normal range for the first time since my original TAC chemo Feb-June this year. It has been much easier on me than TAC.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2014 06:13PM christina1961 wrote: Netty, I'm on tamoxifen for 5-10% ER positivity, PR negative.  I don't like the side effects (weight gain, depression, fatigue) but I'm afraid not to take it.  I went to three oncologists for an opinion, two that are triple negative specialists (UNC and Vanderbilt).  My local oncologist and the UNC oncologist strongly recommend the tamoxifen to be followed by an AI. My local oncologist wants me on some type of anti-hormonal for 10 years.  The Vanderbilt oncologist said if I had side effects I could probably quit taking it.  I continue to take it just in case and because 2 out of 3 recommend it.
Posts.Title: Slightly positive for ER Nettie1964 HomeMom

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2011 04:56PM christina1961 wrote: Thanks, Claire!  I'm glad to hear that - I have ER+PR- also and have been on Arimidex for a little over a month even though my ER receptors are only 5-10%.  I'm having joint pain and am a little discouraged but grateful if it helps me!  I used to cycle 20-30 miles 3-4 days a week but a couple years before diagnosis I was so tired and working a lot so I got out of shape. I've started back walking 4 miles several days a week and hope to start cycling again soon. I may be having more chemo in a trial setting, not sure yet - but am due to start radiation soon, too.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2011 11:56PM christina1961 wrote: I don't have any words of wisdom but remember you do have Herceptin and the endocrine therapy to help you, too.  My sister didn't have neoadjuvant chemo- she had surgery first but her tumor was over 6 cm (ILC) and she had 10 of 12 nodes positive.  She is almost 5 years out - and she was HER- but strongly ER positive.  She takes Femara.  I had residual disease following my neoadjuvant chemo and I am searching for a way to get additional chemo as I am almost triple negative. (Since my estrogen positivity is so low, the benefit I will get from tamoxifen is less certain.) There are three trials that I know of  that are ongoing for patients who have residual disease left following neo chemo- one is out of Sarah Cannon cancer center in Nashville (with locations all over the country); one is from Brown University and has treatment in Rhode Island and New Mexico, and one is from Dana Farber with locations all over the country.  There is also one in NC but it is for triple negative breast cancer. Hope this helps, and I wish you the very best.
